texts:
3rd year Mechatronics Undergraduate at 
The University of Melbourne
Precision motion control through custom gearbox design
Modular design for adaptive humanoid systems
Precision manufacturing from digital to physical

A 4-DOF robot arm built from scratch using NEMA 17 motors and Arduino Uno with CNC shield control. Each joint employs a different gearbox design, creating a comprehensive study in mechanical power transmission.
Upgraded Joint 2 to a 100:1 ratio cycloidal planetary gearbox, addressing backlash and motion precision issues from the original design.
Successfully designed, manufactured, and integrated four distinct gearbox architectures in a single robotic system, demonstrating deep understanding of mechanical power transmission principles.
Each joint responds to a user-specified angle inputted through Arduino IDE serial monitor
Two-phase planetary using standard spur gears for speed reduction and torque multiplication.
Backlash issue: Gear spacing creates shock when switching directions due to momentary gear separation.
Cycloidal disc mechanism for high reduction in compact form.
Tolerance nightmare: Required multiple redesigns and reprints. Screw dowels caused backlash and elliptical output motion.
Uses cycloidal herringbone gears for self-alignment and zero backlash.
3D print optimized: Thicker profiles and larger root fillets reduce stress concentration and tolerance sensitivity.

Engineering Insight: Cycloidal tooth profiles provide near-zero backlash through continuous rolling contact and high tooth overlap, while herringbone geometry cancels axial forces, making this design superior for precision robotics applications.
Output shaft connected using screws as dowels created significant play in the system
Backlash caused delayed response in output motion, reducing precision
Imperfections resulted in non-circular motion path
Limited materials and tolerance issues in the cycloidal design necessitated a complete redesign using proven cycloidal planetary architecture.
Two-phase version of the successful 10:1 gearbox design
5x higher ratio (100:1 vs 20:1) with improved precision
Leveraged lessons from Joint 3 to achieve proper tolerances
Takeaways: Engineering excellence emerges from iterative refinement. Each failure provides data for the next design, transforming theoretical knowledge into practical mastery.
A modular torso system designed for continuous expansion and adaptability. The architecture enables easy addition of storage and electronics while maintaining structural integrity.
Case designed in sections for printability, assembled with wood filler for seamless finish, then painted for professional appearance.
Torso responds to user specified angle inputs through programmed motor control.
Innovation: The modular approach enables future expansion without redesign, demonstrating forward-thinking engineering for evolving project requirements.
Inspired by wrist differential mechanisms, this head control system achieves two degrees of freedom using only two motors through clever differential gearing.
Complete control algorithms and motor coordination logic documented on GitHub.
Engineering Principle: Differential mechanisms achieve multiple degrees of freedom with fewer actuators, reducing weight, cost, and control complexity
Design and build a car-like robot capable of detecting obstacles and autonomously navigating around them. A self-directed project outside university coursework.
DC motors + wheels + metal ball caster
Complete chassis designed in OnShape CAD, ensuring proper component fitment before manufacturing.
Custom firmware for sensor reading, decision making, and motor control
Successfully demonstrated autonomous obstacle detection and avoidance behavior in real-world testing scenarios.
The inaugural university project: use Simulink to control a robot to follow a line, detect an object, pick it up, and place it in a designated location.
Robot didn't complete the full course due to time constraints but provided invaluable learning experiences.
Programs crashed repeatedly, required restarts from scratch
First SolidWorks experience for gripper design
Learned slicing workflow and print parameters
State models for robot behavior logic
Foundation Building: This project established the fundamental skills: CAD, control systems, 3D printing, debugging.
Learn CNC milling machine operation by designing and manufacturing a functional bottle opener from raw stock to finished product.
Manufacturing Competency: Complete digital to physical workflow mastery, from CAD design through CAM programming to precision CNC machining.
Designed for university CAD workshop with complete documentation
AI-powered image to 3D using Bambu Studio
Family portrait that reveals image when backlit
Photo → ChatGPT cartoon → statue → Bambu Studio
Additive Manufacturing skill: From functional mechanical designs to artistic applications, demonstrates versatility across the full spectrum of 3D printing capabilities.
My inception point, where everything began
Aluminium Cans to Sapphire: The Project That Started It All
Born from a friend's joke: "Wouldn't it be cool if we turned aluminium cans into ruby?" This project launched my engineering journey and won science fair awards.
Melt cans to obtain pure aluminium
Safety Note: No injuries occurred. Route 2 developed to avoid chlorine gas from Route 1.
Aluminium Cans to Sapphire: The Project That Started It All
My first independent circuit project, a simple traffic light system that established the electronic foundation for all future robotics work.
Coded in C language, implementing timing logic for realistic traffic light sequencing.
These basic skills: circuit design, programming, debugging
